Sub-themes: ''Continents, countries and nationalities, shopping for personal food preference, food and food culture from different parts of the world''
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for continents: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, Australia,
Oceans: (The Pacific, Atlantic, Arctic, Indian and Southern Oceans) Verbs: To be surrounded.
Vocabulary for countries and nationalities:
Countries: Türkiye, United Kingdom-UK (England, Northern Ireland, Scotland, Wales), Great Briain-GB (informal) (England, Scotland, Wales), Belgium, Croatia, Czech Republic/Czechia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Bulgaria, Hungary, Italy, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, China, Japan, Russia, India, the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus.
Nationalities: Turkish, English, Irish, Scottish, Welsh, Belgian, Croatian, Czech, Danish, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Bulgarian, Hungarian, Italian, Dutch, Polish, Portuguese, Spanish, Swedish, Swiss, Chinese, Japanese, Russian, Indian, Turkish Cypriot.
Vocabulary for shopping for personal food preferences:
Vocabulary for food types:
Adjectives: Gluten-free, dairy-free, sugar-free, halal, homemade, spicy, sweet, salty, bitter, sour, delicious, grilled, boiled. Nouns: Fast food, a traditional dish, a main course, a side dish, a dessert. Verbs: To buy, to order, to pay (in cash/ by credit-debit card), to ask (for).
Vocabulary for people according to food preferences:
Nouns: A vegan, a vegetarian.
Vocabulary for places, items, and people about food:
Nouns: A supermarket, a shop (store-AmE), a shelf, a trolley-Cart-AmE), a cashier, a receipt, a discount, a price, a sale, a snack.
Vocabulary for healthy food:
Nouns: Vegetables (beans, a carrot, garlic, a mushroom, an onion), fruit (grapes).
Vocabulary for unhealthy Food:
Nouns: A burger, a biscuit (cookie-AmE), cereal, chips (French fries-AmE), fried food.
Vocabulary for food and food culture from different parts of the world:
Nouns: Pizza, pasta, sushi, croissant, chopsticks, falafel, sandwich, steak, fish and chips, kebab, rice.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days,
festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Comparative Adjectives: (This curry is spicier than the one last week.)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
- The Present Perfect Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (They’ve / have eaten all the food since yesterday evening. They haven’t / have not eaten all the food yesterday. (Have they eaten all the food yesterday?)
-Question Tags with the Present Perfect Tense: (You have finished your food, haven’t you?)
With How Long? Since, For, Already, Just, Ever, Never):
How Long?: (How long have you shopped for traditional dishes?)
Since: (She has lived in Italy since 2020 and she loves Italian pasta.)
For: (I have been a vegetarian for three years.)
Already: (They have already tried kebab in Türkiye.)
Just: (We have just bought some fresh vegetables from the supermarket.)
Ever: (Have you ever tasted falafel from the Middle East?)
Never: (I have never eaten spicy Japanese food before.)
-Superlative Adjectives (Regular and irregular adjectives)
Regular: (Italy has the most delicious pasta dishes in the world.)
Irregular: (This is the best croissant I’ve ever eaten!)
-Countable and Uncountable Nouns:
Countable nouns (for food): (There are many baklavas in the shop window.)
Uncountable nouns (for food): (There is some rice in the pot.)
-Quantifiers: Some, any, much, many, a lot of, none, no, few, a few, little, a little
Little: (There is little rice left in the bag; we need to buy more.)
A Little: (I added a little garlic to the soup for extra flavour.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of Comparative Adjectives: Comparing differences between two people, places, things, or ideas and showing how one thing differs from another in terms of a quality or characteristic.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Present Perfect Tense (With How Long? Since, For, Already, Just, Ever, Never): Describing
actions or events that have a connection to the present; expressing duration, completion, or experience.
-Use of ''Question Tags'' with the Present Perfect Tense: Confirming information or seeking agreement
about actions or events that have a connection to the present.
-Use of Superlative Adjectives (Regular and Irregular Adjectives): Comparing more than two items or people to highlight the highest degree of a quality.
-Use of Countable and Uncountable Nouns: Differentiating between items that can be individually counted and those that cannot; describing quantities and making appropriate agreements with verbs and quantifiers.
-Use of Quantifiers: Some, any, much, many, a lot of, none, no, few, a few, little, a little: Describing and
specifying amounts or quantities of countable and uncountable nouns in various contexts.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
The four corners of the world!
East meets West!
Shop till you drop!
You are what you eat!
We’re cooking up a storm!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonants: j, k
j: (/dʒeɪ/, /dʒ/); k: (/k/), silent /k/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

PERFORMANCE ASSIGNMENT: Students will design and write a project about a simple global culinary
adventure. In this project, they will pile up a booklet about culinary adventures to explore continents,
countries, and food cultures of various regions. They will describe personal food preferences and shopping

from various cultures around the world. The assignment will be evaluated using rubrics.

Sub-themes: "Daily activities in nature, extreme weather conditions and adventures in nature"
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for nature:
Nouns: A field, a mountain, a hill, a valley, a forest, a jungle, a river, a lake, the sea, an ocean, a beach, an island, a cave, a tree, a plant, a leaf, a rock, sand, soil, grass.
Vocabulary for daily activities and nature:
Nouns: Gardening, growing vegetables, taking a walk, having a picnic, mowing the lawn/cutting the grass, riding a horse/ a bike, enjoying the view, planting a tree, watering the plants. Verbs: To grow, to plant, to water, to gather, to pick, to take care (of), to protect, to save, to recycle, to feed, to collect.
Vocabulary for activities in nature:
Verbs: To go fishing, to swim, to explore, to rest, to ride a bike/to cycle.
Vocabulary for extreme weather conditions:
Nouns: A thunderstorm, lightning, a storm (hurricane, AmE), the temperature. Adjectives: Dangerous,
severe, stormy.
Vocabulary for adventures in nature:
Nouns: Camping, climbing, snowboarding, surfing, diving, canoeing, mountain biking. Equipment for
adventures: A tent, a backpack, a map. Adjectives: Exciting, peaceful, dangerous, amazing, adventurous.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days,
festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social cultural,and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Simple Past Tense with Regular and Irregular Verbs (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (We explored the forest yesterday and found a beautiful waterfall. We explored the forest yesterday but we didn't/did not find anything. Did you find anything when you explored the forest yesterday?)
-WH-questions: (Why): (Why did they climb up those dangerous mountains yesterday?
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Past Progressive Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (They were hiking up the mountain when the lightning struck. They weren’t / were not hiking up the mountain when the lightning
struck because the weather was too dangerous. Were they hiking up the mountain when the lightning struck?)
-The Past Progressive versus The Simple Past Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (While
we were having a picnic by the river, a sudden rainstorm began.) (He wasn’t watering the plants when the wind knocked over the pots.) (What were you doing when the temperature dropped suddenly?)
-Modal ''Could'' for Ability in the Past: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms):
(He could climb the steep hill with ease during the hiking trip. He couldn’t / could not climb the steep hill with ease during the hiking trip. Could he climb the steep hill with ease during the hiking trip?)
-Modal ''Should'' for Advice: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (You should wear a helmet while mountain biking on rough terrain. You shouldn’t /should not wear a helmet while mountain biking on rough terrain. Should she wear a helmet while mountain biking on rough terrain?)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Simple Past Tense with Regular and Irregular Verbs: Talking about actions or events that happened and finished in the past.
- Use of WH-questions: Why: Asking for reasons, purposes, or explanations for actions or events.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Past Progressive Tense: Describing ongoing or interrupted actions in the past; setting the background for a narrative.
-Use of the Past Progressive versus The Simple Past Tense: Contrasting an ongoing action with a completed action in the past; showing which action was in progress when another action occurred.
-Use of Modal ''Could'' for Ability in the Past: Describing abilities or possibilities in the past; expressing what someone was capable of doing.
-Use of Modal ''Should'' for Advice: Giving recommendations, suggestions or expressing opinions about what is appropriate or advisable.
-Use of Modal ''Will'' for Help: Offering assistance or making promises related to future actions.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
I enjoy being close to nature!
The wind blew me away!
It was boiling all day today!
Nature takes our breath away!
Camping under the stars in the mountains is marvellous!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonants: l, m
l: (/ɛl/ /l/, silent /l/); m; (/ɛm/, /m/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

Assessment and Evaluation Scheme for Upper Secondary Schools

PERFORMANCE ASSIGNMENT: Students will design and write a project based on their experiences and
imagination of daily activities in nature, extreme weather conditions, and adventures in nature. They will
describe the roles people play in different outdoor activities, how weather conditions influence those
activities, and the necessary preparations for adventures in nature. Students will write scripts for each
role and act out different scenarios involving nature-based activities like hiking, camping, or experiencing
extreme weather conditions. The assignment will be evaluated using rubrics.

Expansion
Objective: To describe past actions and events to create a story by using the target vocabulary and the target grammar.

Objective: To describe what people were doing in nature in the past in English by using the target vocabulary and the target grammar.

konu:
Sub-themes: "Daily activities in nature, extreme weather conditions and adventures in nature"
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for nature:
Nouns: A field, a mountain, a hill, a valley, a forest, a jungle, a river, a lake, the sea, an ocean, a beach, an island, a cave, a tree, a plant, a leaf, a rock, sand, soil, grass.
Vocabulary for daily activities and nature:
Nouns: Gardening, growing vegetables, taking a walk, having a picnic, mowing the lawn/cutting the grass, riding a horse/ a bike, enjoying the view, planting a tree, watering the plants. Verbs: To grow, to plant, to water, to gather, to pick, to take care (of), to protect, to save, to recycle, to feed, to collect.
Vocabulary for activities in nature:
Verbs: To go fishing, to swim, to explore, to rest, to ride a bike/to cycle.
Vocabulary for extreme weather conditions:
Nouns: A thunderstorm, lightning, a storm (hurricane, AmE), the temperature. Adjectives: Dangerous,
severe, stormy.
Vocabulary for adventures in nature:
Nouns: Camping, climbing, snowboarding, surfing, diving, canoeing, mountain biking. Equipment for
adventures: A tent, a backpack, a map. Adjectives: Exciting, peaceful, dangerous, amazing, adventurous.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days,
festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social cultural,and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Simple Past Tense with Regular and Irregular Verbs (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (We explored the forest yesterday and found a beautiful waterfall. We explored the forest yesterday but we didn't/did not find anything. Did you find anything when you explored the forest yesterday?)
-WH-questions: (Why): (Why did they climb up those dangerous mountains yesterday?
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Past Progressive Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (They were hiking up the mountain when the lightning struck. They weren’t / were not hiking up the mountain when the lightning
struck because the weather was too dangerous. Were they hiking up the mountain when the lightning struck?)
-The Past Progressive versus The Simple Past Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (While
we were having a picnic by the river, a sudden rainstorm began.) (He wasn’t watering the plants when the wind knocked over the pots.) (What were you doing when the temperature dropped suddenly?)
-Modal ''Could'' for Ability in the Past: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms):
(He could climb the steep hill with ease during the hiking trip. He couldn’t / could not climb the steep hill with ease during the hiking trip. Could he climb the steep hill with ease during the hiking trip?)
-Modal ''Should'' for Advice: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (You should wear a helmet while mountain biking on rough terrain. You shouldn’t /should not wear a helmet while mountain biking on rough terrain. Should she wear a helmet while mountain biking on rough terrain?)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Simple Past Tense with Regular and Irregular Verbs: Talking about actions or events that happened and finished in the past.
- Use of WH-questions: Why: Asking for reasons, purposes, or explanations for actions or events.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Past Progressive Tense: Describing ongoing or interrupted actions in the past; setting the background for a narrative.
-Use of the Past Progressive versus The Simple Past Tense: Contrasting an ongoing action with a completed action in the past; showing which action was in progress when another action occurred.
-Use of Modal ''Could'' for Ability in the Past: Describing abilities or possibilities in the past; expressing what someone was capable of doing.
-Use of Modal ''Should'' for Advice: Giving recommendations, suggestions or expressing opinions about what is appropriate or advisable.
-Use of Modal ''Will'' for Help: Offering assistance or making promises related to future actions.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
I enjoy being close to nature!
The wind blew me away!
It was boiling all day today!
Nature takes our breath away!
Camping under the stars in the mountains is marvellous!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonants: l, m
l: (/ɛl/ /l/, silent /l/); m; (/ɛm/, /m/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

Sub-themes: "Planets and satellites in the solar system, facts about planets, the Earth as a planet"
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for planets and satellites in the solar system: The Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Mercury, Venus, Uranus, Neptune, Pluto (a dwarf planet).
Nouns: Space, a star, the sun, the moon, an atmosphere, sky, an orbit, an asteroid, gases, temperature, gravity, a crater, an idea, a project, a planet, a rocket, an astronaut. Adjectives: Large, tiny, extreme.
Vocabulary for facts about planets:
Nouns: Air, oxygen, carbon dioxide, an astronaut, a galaxy, an eclipse, a force, a hemisphere, a meteor, a surface, a layer, a telescope, a scientist. Verbs: To explore, to discover, to analyse, to monitor, to observe, to measure, to breathe, to create, to build, to dream, to travel.
Vocabulary for the Earth as a planet:
Nouns: A continent, a country, a climate, an equator, Northern and Southern hemispheres, The North
Pole and South Pole, a natural disaster, an earthquake, a volcanic eruption, a tsunami, erosion, a habitat, a civilisation, pollution, a resource, a smart city.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al- Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Simple Future Tense (Will) (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (Scientists will send new
robots to explore the surface of Mars next year.) (Scientists won’t / will not send new robots to explore the surface of Mars next year.) (Will scientists send new robots to explore the surface of Mars next year?)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Zero Conditional: (If you travel to Mars, you need to wear a spacesuit because there is no oxygen in the atmosphere.)
-First Conditional (1): (If the weather on Earth continues to change, we will experience more natural disasters like cyclones.)
-With ''Unless'': (Unless we protect the environment, pollution will continue to harm the planet.)
-With ''If'': (If we discover new planets, we can learn more about the possibility of life in space.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Simple Future Tense: Talking about predictions, plans, promises, or decisions about the future.
-Use of the Simple Present Tense: Describing facts and general truths.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the ''Zero Conditional'': Describing general truths, facts, or habitual actions that are always true if certain conditions are met
-Use of the ''First Conditional (1)'': Describing possible or likely outcomes in the future based on a condition being fulfilled
-Use of ''Unless'': Expressing a condition in a negative form, indicating something will happen only if the condition is not met
-Use of ''If'': Introducing a condition to describe potential actions, situations, or consequences, often
expressing possibility or uncertainty
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
I’m lost in the cosmos!
She’s over the moon!
Starry eyed dreams!
We’re orbiting the same idea!
That’s the gravity of the situation!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonant: n, (n-g)
n: (/ɛn/, /n/); ng: (/ng/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

Objective: To describe planets and satellites in the solar system in English by using target vocabulary.

konu:
Sub-themes: "Planets and satellites in the solar system, facts about planets, the Earth as a planet"
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for planets and satellites in the solar system: The Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Mercury, Venus, Uranus, Neptune, Pluto (a dwarf planet).
Nouns: Space, a star, the sun, the moon, an atmosphere, sky, an orbit, an asteroid, gases, temperature, gravity, a crater, an idea, a project, a planet, a rocket, an astronaut. Adjectives: Large, tiny, extreme.
Vocabulary for facts about planets:
Nouns: Air, oxygen, carbon dioxide, an astronaut, a galaxy, an eclipse, a force, a hemisphere, a meteor, a surface, a layer, a telescope, a scientist. Verbs: To explore, to discover, to analyse, to monitor, to observe, to measure, to breathe, to create, to build, to dream, to travel.
Vocabulary for the Earth as a planet:
Nouns: A continent, a country, a climate, an equator, Northern and Southern hemispheres, The North
Pole and South Pole, a natural disaster, an earthquake, a volcanic eruption, a tsunami, erosion, a habitat, a civilisation, pollution, a resource, a smart city.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al- Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Simple Future Tense (Will) (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (Scientists will send new
robots to explore the surface of Mars next year.) (Scientists won’t / will not send new robots to explore the surface of Mars next year.) (Will scientists send new robots to explore the surface of Mars next year?)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Zero Conditional: (If you travel to Mars, you need to wear a spacesuit because there is no oxygen in the atmosphere.)
-First Conditional (1): (If the weather on Earth continues to change, we will experience more natural disasters like cyclones.)
-With ''Unless'': (Unless we protect the environment, pollution will continue to harm the planet.)
-With ''If'': (If we discover new planets, we can learn more about the possibility of life in space.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Simple Future Tense: Talking about predictions, plans, promises, or decisions about the future.
-Use of the Simple Present Tense: Describing facts and general truths.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the ''Zero Conditional'': Describing general truths, facts, or habitual actions that are always true if certain conditions are met
-Use of the ''First Conditional (1)'': Describing possible or likely outcomes in the future based on a condition being fulfilled
-Use of ''Unless'': Expressing a condition in a negative form, indicating something will happen only if the condition is not met
-Use of ''If'': Introducing a condition to describe potential actions, situations, or consequences, often
expressing possibility or uncertainty
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
I’m lost in the cosmos!
She’s over the moon!
Starry eyed dreams!
We’re orbiting the same idea!
That’s the gravity of the situation!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonant: n, (n-g)
n: (/ɛn/, /n/); ng: (/ng/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Present Simple Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (Students always wear their
school uniforms). Students don’t / do not wear their school uniforms every day). (Do students always wear their school uniforms?)
-The Present Progressive Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (They are building the new
library near the science block this week They aren’t / are not building the new library near the science block this week. Are they building the new library near the science block this week?)
-The Simple Past Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (Students gathered in the assembly hall two days ago.) (Students didn’t / did not gather in the assembly hall two days ago. Did the students gather in the assembly hall two days ago?)
-The Past Progressive Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (They were painting the
classroom in the winter break. They weren’t / were not painting the classroom in the winter break. Were
they painting the classroom in the winter break?)
-Questions Tags for the Present and Past Tenses: (You are coming to the school, aren’t you? / You aren’t/are not coming to the party, are you?).
-Some Pronouns: something, anything
-Used to: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (I used to think Maths was hard, but I enjoy it.) (I didn’t use to study Maths when I was younger. Did you use to study Maths when you were younger?)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Passive Voice in Present Tenses (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Passive Present (The homework is given by the teacher every day. The homework isn’t / is not given by the teacher every day. Is the homework given by the teacher every day?)
-The Passive Voice in Past Tenses (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The classroom was cleaned by the management after the art project. The classroom wasn’t/was not cleaned by the management after the art project. Was the classroom cleaned by the management after the art project?) (The exam results were announced by the teacher yesterday. The exam results weren’t /were not announced by the teacher yesterday. Were the exam results announced by the teacher yesterday?) (The classroom was being cleaned by the caretaker. The classroom wasn’t / was not being cleaned by the caretaker. Was the classroom being cleaned by the caretaker?) (The walls were being decorated for the school festival. The walls weren’t / were not being decorated for the school festival. Were the walls being decorated for the school festival?)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Simple Present Tense: Describing actions, habits, routines, general truths or facts that are
always permanent.
-Use of the Present Progressive Tense: (Also called the Present Continuous Tense). Describing actions or situations that are happening now and temporary actions or events that are in progress but not permanent, and fixed future plans.
-Use of the of the Simple Past Tense: Describing finished actions and events at a specific time in the past and are now finished; a sequence of actions that occurred in the past; and past habits.
- Use of the Past Progressive Tense: (Also called the Past Continuous Tense). Describing actions in progress at a moment in the past, setting the scene, simultaneous actions, and interruptions.
- Use of ''Question Tags'': Confirming information, seeking agreement, expressing surprise or doubt.
-Use of Some Pronouns (something, anything):
"Something'': Referring to a specific, unknown, or indefinite object or thing in a positive or affirmative
context.
"Anything": Referring to negative statements, questions, or conditional sentences.
-Use of ''Used to'': Referring to past habits, or states that are no longer apply.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of Passive Voice: Describing the situation where the focus is on the action or the receiver of the action, rather than who or what is doing it.

Vowel: o
Vowel: o: (/əʊ/, /ɒ/, /əʊ/)

A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Present Simple Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (Students always wear their
school uniforms). Students don’t / do not wear their school uniforms every day). (Do students always wear their school uniforms?)
-The Present Progressive Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (They are building the new
library near the science block this week They aren’t / are not building the new library near the science block this week. Are they building the new library near the science block this week?)
-The Simple Past Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (Students gathered in the assembly hall two days ago.) (Students didn’t / did not gather in the assembly hall two days ago. Did the students gather in the assembly hall two days ago?)
-The Past Progressive Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (They were painting the
classroom in the winter break. They weren’t / were not painting the classroom in the winter break. Were
they painting the classroom in the winter break?)
-Questions Tags for the Present and Past Tenses: (You are coming to the school, aren’t you? / You aren’t/are not coming to the party, are you?).
-Some Pronouns: something, anything
-Used to: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (I used to think Maths was hard, but I enjoy it.) (I didn’t use to study Maths when I was younger. Did you use to study Maths when you were younger?)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Passive Voice in Present Tenses (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Passive Present (The homework is given by the teacher every day. The homework isn’t / is not given by the teacher every day. Is the homework given by the teacher every day?)
-The Passive Voice in Past Tenses (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The classroom was cleaned by the management after the art project. The classroom wasn’t/was not cleaned by the management after the art project. Was the classroom cleaned by the management after the art project?) (The exam results were announced by the teacher yesterday. The exam results weren’t /were not announced by the teacher yesterday. Were the exam results announced by the teacher yesterday?) (The classroom was being cleaned by the caretaker. The classroom wasn’t / was not being cleaned by the caretaker. Was the classroom being cleaned by the caretaker?) (The walls were being decorated for the school festival. The walls weren’t / were not being decorated for the school festival. Were the walls being decorated for the school festival?)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Simple Present Tense: Describing actions, habits, routines, general truths or facts that are
always permanent.
-Use of the Present Progressive Tense: (Also called the Present Continuous Tense). Describing actions or situations that are happening now and temporary actions or events that are in progress but not permanent, and fixed future plans.
-Use of the of the Simple Past Tense: Describing finished actions and events at a specific time in the past and are now finished; a sequence of actions that occurred in the past; and past habits.
- Use of the Past Progressive Tense: (Also called the Past Continuous Tense). Describing actions in progress at a moment in the past, setting the scene, simultaneous actions, and interruptions.
- Use of ''Question Tags'': Confirming information, seeking agreement, expressing surprise or doubt.
-Use of Some Pronouns (something, anything):
"Something'': Referring to a specific, unknown, or indefinite object or thing in a positive or affirmative
context.
"Anything": Referring to negative statements, questions, or conditional sentences.
-Use of ''Used to'': Referring to past habits, or states that are no longer apply.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of Passive Voice: Describing the situation where the focus is on the action or the receiver of the action, rather than who or what is doing it.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
We’re in the same boat!
We have a school spirit!
Let’s get a head start at school this year!
Remember! Even a bad day doesn’t last forever.
It’s a marathon, not a sprint!
One step at a time!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Vowel: o
Vowel: o: (/əʊ/, /ɒ/, /əʊ/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

Can’t: (She can’t be at school today; she was absent yesterday and said she would be sick for the week.)
Must: (You must study for the test if you want to get a good mark.)
Have to: (I have to attend the lesson it’s necessary for my graduation.)
-Could for Ability and Probability: (When I was younger, I could speak three languages fluently.)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Passive Voice in Future Tenses and Modals:
-Passive Voice in the Simple Future Tense (Will) (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The new smart boards will be installed in all classrooms by next month.) (The new smart boards won’t / will not be installed in all classrooms by next month). (Will the new smart boards be installed in all classrooms by next month?)
- Passive Voice in ''Be Going to Future'' Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (AI-powered tools are going to be introduced in the digital skills course. AI-powered tools aren’t / are not going to be introduced in the digital skills course. Are AI-powered tools going to be introduced in the digital skills course?)
-Passive Voice in the Simple Present Tense for the Future (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (A coding workshop is held every Friday at 3 p.m. A coding workshop isn’t / is not held every Friday at 3 p.m. Is a coding workshop held every Friday at 3 p.m.?)
-Passive Voice in the Present Progressive Tense for the Future (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (New tablets are being delivered to the school next week. New tablets aren’t / are not being delivered to the school next week. Are new tablets being delivered to the school next week?)
-Passive Voice with Modals (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The old house might be sold next month. The old house might not be sold next month. Might the old house be sold next month?)
-Reflexive Pronouns (myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves) (I prepared the project myself for the school exhibition.)
-Connecting words expressing cause, effect, contrast, and time:
Cause: (He didn’t / did not finish his homework as he was feeling sick.)
Effect: (She didn’t / did not study for the test, so she failed it.)
Contrast: (He studied all night for the test however he still didn’t / did not do well.)
Time: (I’ll / will wait for you in the cafeteria until the bell rings.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Simple Future Tense: Making predictions, expressing a plan or intention, and asking questions about future actions.
- Use of the ''Be going to Future'' Tense: Expressing planned actions or predictions based on evidence.
-Use of the Simple Present Tense for the Future Tense: Describing the future, especially for scheduled or planned events.
-Use of the Present Progressive Tense for Future Tense: Describing personal plans or fixed arrangements in the future.
-Use of ''Should & Ought to'' for Obligation: Expressing obligation, advice, or recommendations.
Should: Expressing advice and expectation, or indicate an obligation, but with a sense of flexibility. It’s less formal than ''ought to''.
Ought to: Expressing moral obligations or recommendations that feel more serious.
-Use of ''Should'' for Suggestion: Giving suggestions, offering a recommendation or advice on what might be a good idea or what would likely lead to a positive outcome.
-Use of ''Must & Can’t'' for Deduction: Expressing deduction, meaning they help to infer or conclude something based on evidence or logical reasoning.
Must: Expressing a strong belief that something is true based on the evidence or information available.
Can’t: Showing that we are certain something is not true, based on reasoning or evidence. It indicates a strong belief that something is impossible or incorrect.
-Use of ''Must'' vs ''Have to'': Expressing deduction, meaning they help to infer or conclude something based on evidence or logical reasoning.
Must: Expressing internal obligation (the speaker's strong belief or personal requirement) or rules and regulations that are strictly enforced.
Have to: Expressing external obligation that are not directly imposed by the speaker.
-Use of ''Could for Ability and Probability'': Expressing the ability to do something in the past that is not necessarily happens in the present.
-Use of Reflexive Pronouns: Showing the subject and the object of a sentence refer to the same person or thing.
-Use of Connecting words expressing cause, effect, contrast, and time:
Cause: Explaining why something happens, or what the reason behind an event or action is.
Effect: Showing the result or outcome of an action, event, or situation.
Contrast: Showing a difference or opposition between two ideas.
Time: Showing the order of events or help indicate when something happens.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of Passive Voice in the Simple Future Tense: Describing predictions, spontaneous decisions, or future facts, focusing on what will happen to someone/something.
-Use of Passive Voice in the ''Be Going to'' Future Tense: Describing planned actions or intentions, something that has already been decided, not who submits them.
-Use of the Passive Voice in the Simple Present Tense: Describing routines, facts, or general truths where the focus is on the action or result. Focus is on the regular action, not who submits them.
-Use of the Passive Voice in the Present Progressive Tense: Describing personal plans or fixed arrangements in the future, not the doer. Focus is on the ongoing process.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
Practice makes perfect!
Do not/ Don't skip the class!
One step at a time!
I’m all ears for the teacher’s explanations!
Let’s sort this out!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Phonetic sounds: p, q
Consonants: p:(/piː/, /p/); q: (/kjuː/, /k/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

THEME 10: CLASSROOM LIFE AND LEARNING WITH
TECHNOLOGY
konu:
Sub-themes: “Technological classroom tools, learning with technology, future classrooms”
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Technological classroom tools:
Vocabulary for technological devices:
Nouns: A digital camera, a laptop, a PC, a printer, a smartphone, a webcam, a VR headset, a disc/disk, a machine, a robot.
Vocabulary for accessories:
Nouns: A keyboard, a mouse, a mouse mat, a screen.
Vocabulary for general technology:
Nouns: An app, an email, equipment, a server, a fax. Verbs: to switch off/to switch on, to turn on/off a server.
Vocabulary for learning with technology, communication, and interaction:
Nouns: Communication, access, a connection, a text, by post. Verbs: To connect, to communicate, to upload, to download, to log in, to log out, to boost. Adjectives: Digital.
Vocabulary for digital tools and resources:
Nouns: A blog, a podcast, a program(me), social media, software, a website, a web page, the internet (net).
Vocabulary for technological concepts:
Nouns: digital literacy, an application (App), a browser, a digital footprint, netiquette, information.
Vocabulary for learning and engagement:
Nouns and Phrases: Self-paced learning, a wide range of resources, immediate feedback, benefits, a study, quality, quantity, a presentation. Adjectives: Digital.
Vocabulary for innovations and learning platforms:
Nouns and phrases: An invention, virtual reality (VR), artificial intelligence (AI), augmented reality (AR), lifelong learning, a webinar, online.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Simple Future Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (I think an English professor will visit us tomorrow. I think an English professor won’t / will not visit us tomorrow. Do you think an English professor will visit you tomorrow?
- ''Be going to Future Tense'' (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (We’re / are going to go to a digital Science show next weekend. We aren’t / are not going to go to a digital Science show next weekend. Are you going to go to a digital Science show next weekend?)
-The Present Progressive Tense for the Future (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (We’re/are
having a Computer Club meeting on Friday night. We aren’t/are not having a Computer Club meeting on Friday night. (Are having a Computer Club meeting on Friday night?)
-The Simple Present Tense for the Future (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (Our webinar starts at 7 pm every Monday. (Our webinar doesn’t / does not start at 7 pm on Monday). (Does your webinar start at 7 pm on Monday?)
Modals (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms):
Should: (You should complete your homework before you go out to play.)
Ought to: (You ought to be at school on time every day.)
Should: (You should join a study group to prepare for the exams.)
Must: (The teacher is not in the classroom right now. She must be in a meeting.)
Can’t: (She can’t be at school today; she was absent yesterday and said she would be sick for the week.)
Must: (You must study for the test if you want to get a good mark.)
Have to: (I have to attend the lesson it’s necessary for my graduation.)
-Could for Ability and Probability: (When I was younger, I could speak three languages fluently.)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Passive Voice in Future Tenses and Modals:
-Passive Voice in the Simple Future Tense (Will) (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The new smart boards will be installed in all classrooms by next month.) (The new smart boards won’t / will not be installed in all classrooms by next month). (Will the new smart boards be installed in all classrooms by next month?)
- Passive Voice in ''Be Going to Future'' Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (AI-powered tools are going to be introduced in the digital skills course. AI-powered tools aren’t / are not going to be introduced in the digital skills course. Are AI-powered tools going to be introduced in the digital skills course?)
-Passive Voice in the Simple Present Tense for the Future (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (A coding workshop is held every Friday at 3 p.m. A coding workshop isn’t / is not held every Friday at 3 p.m. Is a coding workshop held every Friday at 3 p.m.?)
-Passive Voice in the Present Progressive Tense for the Future (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (New tablets are being delivered to the school next week. New tablets aren’t / are not being delivered to the school next week. Are new tablets being delivered to the school next week?)
-Passive Voice with Modals (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The old house might be sold next month. The old house might not be sold next month. Might the old house be sold next month?)
-Reflexive Pronouns (myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves) (I prepared the project myself for the school exhibition.)
-Connecting words expressing cause, effect, contrast, and time:
Cause: (He didn’t / did not finish his homework as he was feeling sick.)
Effect: (She didn’t / did not study for the test, so she failed it.)
Contrast: (He studied all night for the test however he still didn’t / did not do well.)
Time: (I’ll / will wait for you in the cafeteria until the bell rings.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Simple Future Tense: Making predictions, expressing a plan or intention, and asking questions about future actions.
- Use of the ''Be going to Future'' Tense: Expressing planned actions or predictions based on evidence.
-Use of the Simple Present Tense for the Future Tense: Describing the future, especially for scheduled or planned events.
-Use of the Present Progressive Tense for Future Tense: Describing personal plans or fixed arrangements in the future.
-Use of ''Should & Ought to'' for Obligation: Expressing obligation, advice, or recommendations.
Should: Expressing advice and expectation, or indicate an obligation, but with a sense of flexibility. It’s less formal than ''ought to''.
Ought to: Expressing moral obligations or recommendations that feel more serious.
-Use of ''Should'' for Suggestion: Giving suggestions, offering a recommendation or advice on what might be a good idea or what would likely lead to a positive outcome.
-Use of ''Must & Can’t'' for Deduction: Expressing deduction, meaning they help to infer or conclude something based on evidence or logical reasoning.
Must: Expressing a strong belief that something is true based on the evidence or information available.
Can’t: Showing that we are certain something is not true, based on reasoning or evidence. It indicates a strong belief that something is impossible or incorrect.
-Use of ''Must'' vs ''Have to'': Expressing deduction, meaning they help to infer or conclude something based on evidence or logical reasoning.
Must: Expressing internal obligation (the speaker's strong belief or personal requirement) or rules and regulations that are strictly enforced.
Have to: Expressing external obligation that are not directly imposed by the speaker.
-Use of ''Could for Ability and Probability'': Expressing the ability to do something in the past that is not necessarily happens in the present.
-Use of Reflexive Pronouns: Showing the subject and the object of a sentence refer to the same person or thing.
-Use of Connecting words expressing cause, effect, contrast, and time:
Cause: Explaining why something happens, or what the reason behind an event or action is.
Effect: Showing the result or outcome of an action, event, or situation.
Contrast: Showing a difference or opposition between two ideas.
Time: Showing the order of events or help indicate when something happens.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of Passive Voice in the Simple Future Tense: Describing predictions, spontaneous decisions, or future facts, focusing on what will happen to someone/something.
-Use of Passive Voice in the ''Be Going to'' Future Tense: Describing planned actions or intentions, something that has already been decided, not who submits them.
-Use of the Passive Voice in the Simple Present Tense: Describing routines, facts, or general truths where the focus is on the action or result. Focus is on the regular action, not who submits them.
-Use of the Passive Voice in the Present Progressive Tense: Describing personal plans or fixed arrangements in the future, not the doer. Focus is on the ongoing process.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
Practice makes perfect!
Do not/ Don't skip the class!
One step at a time!
I’m all ears for the teacher’s explanations!
Let’s sort this out!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Phonetic sounds: p, q
Consonants: p:(/piː/, /p/); q: (/kjuː/, /k/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Zero conditional: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (If you eat healthy food, you stay healthy. If you don’t / do not eat healthy food, you get ill more easily. What happens if you don’t / do not drink enough water?)
- First Conditional (1): (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (If you eat more vegetables, you will feel better. If you don’t / do not eat more vegetables, you won’t /will not feel better. What will happen if you don’t/do not eat more vegetables?)
-Comparative and Superlative Adjectives: (as… as, same…as, like, alike): (If you sleep more hours, you’ll / will feel better.) (That was the most relaxing holiday I’ve ever had.)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Second Conditional (2): (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (If I had more time, I would travel the world. If I had more time, I wouldn’t / would not travel the world but work more. Would you travel the world, if you had more time?)
-With ''If Only'': Present: (If only I were/was taller). Past: (If only I had studied harder) (If only I didn’t have the flu, I could go to school today).
- Wish (Was/Were): (I wish I were taller). (I wish she ate more vegetables and less junk food.)
-Adjectives with ''-ing and -ed'' Endings: Relax (-ing/-ed), Excite (-ing/-ed): (Going for a walk in the park is so relaxing. / After my gym session, I feel very relaxed.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Zero conditional: Expressing general truths of facts and cause-effect relationships.
-First Conditional (1): Expressing real or possible situations in the future, where one action or event depends on another.
-Use of Comparative and Superlative Adjectives:
Comparative Adjectives: Expressing how to compare two things or people and show which one has more or less of a particular quality.
Superlative Adjectives: Describing the highest or lowest degree of quality, when comparing three or more things or people.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of Second Conditional (2): Expressing unreal, hypothetical, or unlikely situations in the present or future, and their possible results.
-Use of ''If Only'': Expressing regret or strong wishes for a different present or past situation
-Use of ''Wish (Was/Were)'': Expressing desires, regrets, or hypothetical situations contrary to the current reality (especially about present).
-Adjectives with ''-ing and -ed'' Endings: Describing the thing or situation that causes feelings or emotions, and characteristics.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
She’s in high spirits.
Let’s clear the air with this problem!
You should recharge your batteries!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonant: r
Consonant r: (/ɑː/(Br), silent /r/ (Br), /aɹ/ (AmE), /ɹ/ (AmE), silent /r/ (Br))
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

-Zero conditional: Expressing general truths of facts and cause-effect relationships.
-First Conditional (1): Expressing real or possible situations in the future, where one action or event depends on another.
-Use of Comparative and Superlative Adjectives:
Comparative Adjectives: Expressing how to compare two things or people and show which one has more or less of a particular quality.
Superlative Adjectives: Describing the highest or lowest degree of quality, when comparing three or more things or people.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of Second Conditional (2): Expressing unreal, hypothetical, or unlikely situations in the present or future, and their possible results.
-Use of ''If Only'': Expressing regret or strong wishes for a different present or past situation
-Use of ''Wish (Was/Were)'': Expressing desires, regrets, or hypothetical situations contrary to the current reality (especially about present).
-Adjectives with ''-ing and -ed'' Endings: Describing the thing or situation that causes feelings or emotions, and characteristics.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
She’s in high spirits.
Let’s clear the air with this problem!
You should recharge your batteries!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonant: r
Consonant r: (/ɑː/(Br), silent /r/ (Br), /aɹ/ (AmE), /ɹ/ (AmE), silent /r/ (Br))

tema: THEME 12: FAMILY LIFE AND THE FUTURE
konu:
Sub-themes: “Family members’ future aspirations; family members’ dreams and ambitions”
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for family members’ aspirations and goals:
Nouns: An achievement, an aspiration, an ambition, a challenge, an effort, an occupation, a passion, a qualification, a talent, a vision, confidence, a dream.
Vocabulary for describing character traits:
Adjectives: Ambitious, capable, confident, determined, hopeful, passionate, committed, goal-oriented, successful, gifted.
Vocabulary for achievement:
Verbs: To achieve, to aim, to aspire, to apply, to choose, to dream, to focus, to improve, to succeed, to desire.
Vocabulary for family members’ dreams and ambitions:
Nouns: An ambition, an arrangement, a degree, a desire, a goal, a graduation, a profession, an opportunity, a skill, a task. Verbs: To accomplish, to arrange, to choose, to develop, to wish.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Present Perfect Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (She’s/ has achieved many personal goals through hard work and dedication.) (She hasn’t / has not achieved all her personal goals yet. (Has she achieved her personal goals through hard work and dedication?)
-''Question Tags'' with the Perfect Tense: (You’ve/have achieved the degree you always desired, haven't you?)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Passive Voice for the Perfect Tenses (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The graduation ceremony has been arranged by the school administration.) (The graduation ceremony hasn’t / has not been arranged by the school administration.) (Has the graduation ceremony been arranged by the school administration?)
-The Present Perfect Progressive Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (He has been focusing on improving his coding skills. (He hasn’t / has not been focusing on improving his coding skills. (Has he been focusing on improving his coding skills?)
-''Able to'' (Present, Past, Perfect, Future): (My brother is able to balance his studies and his part-time job.) (Last year, my cousin was able to find a job abroad after months of searching.) (Have you been able to decide which university you want to apply to?) (My sister will be able to travel more when she gets her dream job.)
-Verbs with Gerunds and Infinitives: (She’s / is committed to improving her talent by applying herself every day.) (She aims to open her own gallery.)
-Prepositional Phrases: (With dedication to her ambition, she managed to get an excellent job.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures:
-Use of the Present Perfect Tense: Describing actions or events that started in the past and continue to the present or have present relevance.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Passive Voice in the Perfect Tenses: Highlighting the recipient or result of an action rather than the doer, especially for completed actions with present relevance.
-Use of the Present Perfect Progressive Tense: Indicating actions that started in the past and continue into the present, often with emphasis/duration.
-Use of ''Able to'' (Present, Past, Perfect, Future) for Possibility and Probability: Expressing ability or possibility across different time frames.
-Use of Verbs with Gerund and Infinitive: Expressing preferences, intentions, or purposes through the choice depending on the verb.
-Use of Prepositional Phrases: Providing additional details about time, place, cause, or manner.
-Use of the ''Question Tags'' with the Perfect Tense and the Present Perfect Progressive Tense: Confirming or checking understanding of past actions or ongoing activities.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
We’re always heart to heart as a family!
My father put his foot down (about the matter)!
Let’s keep this in the family!
She’s the black sheep of the family!
Being good at gardening runs in our family!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonants: s, t
Consonants: s: (/s/, /ɛs/, /z/, silent /s/); t: (/tiː/, /t/, silent /t/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

PERFORMANCE ASSIGNMENT: Students write and design a project on ''Family Members’ Future Aspirations,
Dreams, and Ambitions.'' They will describe the ideal aspirations and ambitions of family members, including
the roles each person plays in supporting these dreams, the skills needed, and the actions taken to achieve
these goals. They will write scripts for each role, illustrating how each family member works toward their
individual aspirations, whether it’s academic success, career goals, or personal growth. In the class, they
will act out these roles, showcasing the importance of support, motivation, and effort in achieving their
dreams. The assignment will be evaluated using rubrics.

tema: THEME 12: FAMILY LIFE AND THE FUTURE
konu:
Sub-themes: “Family members’ future aspirations; family members’ dreams and ambitions”
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for family members’ aspirations and goals:
Nouns: An achievement, an aspiration, an ambition, a challenge, an effort, an occupation, a passion, a qualification, a talent, a vision, confidence, a dream.
Vocabulary for describing character traits:
Adjectives: Ambitious, capable, confident, determined, hopeful, passionate, committed, goal-oriented, successful, gifted.
Vocabulary for achievement:
Verbs: To achieve, to aim, to aspire, to apply, to choose, to dream, to focus, to improve, to succeed, to desire.
Vocabulary for family members’ dreams and ambitions:
Nouns: An ambition, an arrangement, a degree, a desire, a goal, a graduation, a profession, an opportunity, a skill, a task. Verbs: To accomplish, to arrange, to choose, to develop, to wish.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Present Perfect Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (She’s/ has achieved many personal goals through hard work and dedication.) (She hasn’t / has not achieved all her personal goals yet. (Has she achieved her personal goals through hard work and dedication?)
-''Question Tags'' with the Perfect Tense: (You’ve/have achieved the degree you always desired, haven't you?)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Passive Voice for the Perfect Tenses (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The graduation ceremony has been arranged by the school administration.) (The graduation ceremony hasn’t / has not been arranged by the school administration.) (Has the graduation ceremony been arranged by the school administration?)
-The Present Perfect Progressive Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (He has been focusing on improving his coding skills. (He hasn’t / has not been focusing on improving his coding skills. (Has he been focusing on improving his coding skills?)
-''Able to'' (Present, Past, Perfect, Future): (My brother is able to balance his studies and his part-time job.) (Last year, my cousin was able to find a job abroad after months of searching.) (Have you been able to decide which university you want to apply to?) (My sister will be able to travel more when she gets her dream job.)
-Verbs with Gerunds and Infinitives: (She’s / is committed to improving her talent by applying herself every day.) (She aims to open her own gallery.)
-Prepositional Phrases: (With dedication to her ambition, she managed to get an excellent job.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures:
-Use of the Present Perfect Tense: Describing actions or events that started in the past and continue to the present or have present relevance.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Passive Voice in the Perfect Tenses: Highlighting the recipient or result of an action rather than the doer, especially for completed actions with present relevance.
-Use of the Present Perfect Progressive Tense: Indicating actions that started in the past and continue into the present, often with emphasis/duration.
-Use of ''Able to'' (Present, Past, Perfect, Future) for Possibility and Probability: Expressing ability or possibility across different time frames.
-Use of Verbs with Gerund and Infinitive: Expressing preferences, intentions, or purposes through the choice depending on the verb.
-Use of Prepositional Phrases: Providing additional details about time, place, cause, or manner.
-Use of the ''Question Tags'' with the Perfect Tense and the Present Perfect Progressive Tense: Confirming or checking understanding of past actions or ongoing activities.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
We’re always heart to heart as a family!
My father put his foot down (about the matter)!
Let’s keep this in the family!
She’s the black sheep of the family!
Being good at gardening runs in our family!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonants: s, t
Consonants: s: (/s/, /ɛs/, /z/, silent /s/); t: (/tiː/, /t/, silent /t/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

Dreams, and Ambitions.'' They will describe the ideal aspirations and ambitions of family members, including
the roles each person plays in supporting these dreams, the skills needed, and the actions taken to achieve

individual aspirations, whether it’s academic success, career goals, or personal growth. In the class, they
will act out these roles, showcasing the importance of support, motivation, and effort in achieving their
dreams. The assignment will be evaluated using rubrics.
