tema:
THEME 13: LIFE IN THE NEIGHBOURHOOD, CITY AND SOCIAL
LIFE
konu:
Sub-themes: “Cultural and historical places in the neighbourhood and the city; festivals and events in the neighbourhood and the city; problems in the neighbourhood and the city”
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for cultural and historical places in the neighbourhood and the city:
Nouns: A (historic) arch, architecture, a castle, a cathedral, a (historic) city wall, a column, a community centre, an exhibition, a fountain, a gallery, a monument, a mosque, a museum, a palace, ruins, a square, a statue, a temple, a theatre, a tomb, a tower. Adjectives: Ancient, artistic, cultural, decorative, famous, historical, local, modern, scenic, significant, traditional, unique, urban.
Vocabulary for festivals and events in the neighbourhood and the city:
Nouns: An (art) exhibition, a carnival, a celebration, a cultural event, a festival, a parade, a performance, a theatre show. Adjectives: Annual, artistic, cultural, exciting, famous, historical, local, magnificent, memorable, remarkable, significant, traditional, unique, vibrant. Verbs: To celebrate, to attend, to organise, to participate, to promote, to enjoy, to display, to experience, to showcase.
Vocabulary for problems in the neighbourhood and the city:
Nouns: Air pollution, a broken road, rubbish (garbage, trash-AmE), litter, a noise pollution, overcrowding, traffic, waste, water pollution. Adjectives: Crowded, unsafe. Verbs: to fix, to reduce, to solve.
Vocabulary for the problems in the neighbourhood:
Nouns: Location, locals (people). Adjectives: Local, located,
Vocabulary for solutions to the problems in the neighbourhood:
Nouns: Accommodation, housing, Verbs: to report.
Vocabulary for the sustainability in the neighbourhood:
Nouns: Green projects, a green space, a recycling bin shelter. Verbs: to recycle.
Vocabulary for eating outside in the neighbourhood:
Nouns: A starter (appetiser-AmE), a takeaway, a street vendor, a delivery.
Vocabulary for the projects for food maintenance and delivery:
Nouns: A meal, an event, a waste.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-''Shall'' for Suggestions and Polite Offers: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Shall we attend the meeting?)
-''Can'' for Polite Requests and Probability: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Can you tell me the fastest way to get to the city centre?)
-''Might'' for Polite Requests and Probability: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Might we take a different route to the concert to avoid traffic?
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Passive Voice with Modals: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The streets must be cleaned
every morning. The streets can’t be / cannot be cleaned in the morning. Might the streets be cleaned in the morning?)
-''Shall'' for Suggestions and Polite Offers: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Shall we attend the meeting?)
-''Can'' for Polite Requests and Probability: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Can you tell me the fastest way to get to the city centre?)
-''Might'' for Polite Requests and Probability: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Might we take a different route to the concert to avoid traffic?)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of ''Shall'' for Suggestions and Polite Offers: Expressing a willingness to do something for someone and making polite suggestions and/or offers, usually with the first person (I/we).
-Use of ''Can'' for Polite requests and Probability: Making polite requests, especially when asking for permission or asking someone to do something, and expressing possibility or probability, particularly when something is likely or achievable.
-Use of ''Might'' for Polite requests and Probability: Expressing more formal or tentative polite requests
than ''can'', showing respect and politeness when asking for permission or making a suggestion. Expressing probability or possibility when something is less certain than with ''can'' or ''will''.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of Passive Voice with Modals: Emphasising the action or the object of the sentence rather than the
subject, especially when the doer is unknown, implied or unimportant.
-Use of ''Shall'' for Suggestions and Polite Offers: Expressing a willingness to do something for someone and making polite suggestions and/or offers, usually with the first person (I/we).
-Use of ''Can'' for Polite requests and Probability: Making polite requests, especially when asking for permission or asking someone to do something, and expressing possibility or probability, particularly when something is likely or achievable.
-Use of ''Might'' for Polite requests and Probability: Expressing more formal or tentative polite requests
than ''can'', showing respect and politeness when asking for permission or making a suggestion. Expressing probability or possibility when something is less certain than with ''can'' or ''will''.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
That’s a blast from the past!
This museum is steeped in history!
This historical ruin is a window into the past!
This food festival is a feast for the senses!
This city never sleeps!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Vowel: u
Vowel: u: (/juː/, /ʌ/, /juː/, silent /u/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

Assessment and Evaluation Scheme for Upper Secondary Schools

PERFORMANCE ASSIGNMENT: Students will design a detailed project exploring the cultural and historical
places, festivals and events, and problems in their neighbourhood and city. The project will start by identifying significant cultural and historical sites, such as monuments, museums, or landmarks, and explaining their importance to the community. Students will also research festivals and events that take place in their
area, discussing how these celebrations bring people together and reflect local traditions. Additionally, the
project will focus on identifying common problems in the neighbourhood and city, such as traffic, pollution,
or lack of public spaces, and students will propose practical solutions to address these issues. The project
will include a written report summarising the findings, supported by visuals such as photographs, maps,
or charts to enhance the presentation. Students are encouraged to interview local residents or use other
resources to gather more insights into the topics. Along with the report, students will prepare a short oral
presentation to share their findings with the class, focusing on the most interesting cultural or historical
aspects, key festivals, and the proposed solutions to local problems. The assignment will be evaluated by
using rubrics.

tema:
THEME 13: LIFE IN THE NEIGHBOURHOOD, CITY AND SOCIAL
LIFE
konu:
Sub-themes: “Cultural and historical places in the neighbourhood and the city; festivals and events in the neighbourhood and the city; problems in the neighbourhood and the city”
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for cultural and historical places in the neighbourhood and the city:
Nouns: A (historic) arch, architecture, a castle, a cathedral, a (historic) city wall, a column, a community centre, an exhibition, a fountain, a gallery, a monument, a mosque, a museum, a palace, ruins, a square, a statue, a temple, a theatre, a tomb, a tower. Adjectives: Ancient, artistic, cultural, decorative, famous, historical, local, modern, scenic, significant, traditional, unique, urban.
Vocabulary for festivals and events in the neighbourhood and the city:
Nouns: An (art) exhibition, a carnival, a celebration, a cultural event, a festival, a parade, a performance, a theatre show. Adjectives: Annual, artistic, cultural, exciting, famous, historical, local, magnificent, memorable, remarkable, significant, traditional, unique, vibrant. Verbs: To celebrate, to attend, to organise, to participate, to promote, to enjoy, to display, to experience, to showcase.
Vocabulary for problems in the neighbourhood and the city:
Nouns: Air pollution, a broken road, rubbish (garbage, trash-AmE), litter, a noise pollution, overcrowding, traffic, waste, water pollution. Adjectives: Crowded, unsafe. Verbs: to fix, to reduce, to solve.
Vocabulary for the problems in the neighbourhood:
Nouns: Location, locals (people). Adjectives: Local, located,
Vocabulary for solutions to the problems in the neighbourhood:
Nouns: Accommodation, housing, Verbs: to report.
Vocabulary for the sustainability in the neighbourhood:
Nouns: Green projects, a green space, a recycling bin shelter. Verbs: to recycle.
Vocabulary for eating outside in the neighbourhood:
Nouns: A starter (appetiser-AmE), a takeaway, a street vendor, a delivery.
Vocabulary for the projects for food maintenance and delivery:
Nouns: A meal, an event, a waste.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-''Shall'' for Suggestions and Polite Offers: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Shall we attend the meeting?)
-''Can'' for Polite Requests and Probability: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Can you tell me the fastest way to get to the city centre?)
-''Might'' for Polite Requests and Probability: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Might we take a different route to the concert to avoid traffic?
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Passive Voice with Modals: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The streets must be cleaned
every morning. The streets can’t be / cannot be cleaned in the morning. Might the streets be cleaned in the morning?)
-''Shall'' for Suggestions and Polite Offers: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Shall we attend the meeting?)
-''Can'' for Polite Requests and Probability: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Can you tell me the fastest way to get to the city centre?)
-''Might'' for Polite Requests and Probability: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): Might we take a different route to the concert to avoid traffic?)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of ''Shall'' for Suggestions and Polite Offers: Expressing a willingness to do something for someone and making polite suggestions and/or offers, usually with the first person (I/we).
-Use of ''Can'' for Polite requests and Probability: Making polite requests, especially when asking for permission or asking someone to do something, and expressing possibility or probability, particularly when something is likely or achievable.
-Use of ''Might'' for Polite requests and Probability: Expressing more formal or tentative polite requests
than ''can'', showing respect and politeness when asking for permission or making a suggestion. Expressing probability or possibility when something is less certain than with ''can'' or ''will''.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of Passive Voice with Modals: Emphasising the action or the object of the sentence rather than the
subject, especially when the doer is unknown, implied or unimportant.
-Use of ''Shall'' for Suggestions and Polite Offers: Expressing a willingness to do something for someone and making polite suggestions and/or offers, usually with the first person (I/we).
-Use of ''Can'' for Polite requests and Probability: Making polite requests, especially when asking for permission or asking someone to do something, and expressing possibility or probability, particularly when something is likely or achievable.
-Use of ''Might'' for Polite requests and Probability: Expressing more formal or tentative polite requests
than ''can'', showing respect and politeness when asking for permission or making a suggestion. Expressing probability or possibility when something is less certain than with ''can'' or ''will''.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
That’s a blast from the past!
This museum is steeped in history!
This historical ruin is a window into the past!
This food festival is a feast for the senses!
This city never sleeps!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Vowel: u
Vowel: u: (/juː/, /ʌ/, /juː/, silent /u/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

Assessment and Evaluation Scheme for Upper Secondary Schools

PERFORMANCE ASSIGNMENT: Students will design a detailed project exploring the cultural and historical
places, festivals and events, and problems in their neighbourhood and city. The project will start by identifying significant cultural and historical sites, such as monuments, museums, or landmarks, and explaining their importance to the community. Students will also research festivals and events that take place in their
area, discussing how these celebrations bring people together and reflect local traditions. Additionally, the
project will focus on identifying common problems in the neighbourhood and city, such as traffic, pollution,
or lack of public spaces, and students will propose practical solutions to address these issues. The project
will include a written report summarising the findings, supported by visuals such as photographs, maps,
or charts to enhance the presentation. Students are encouraged to interview local residents or use other
resources to gather more insights into the topics. Along with the report, students will prepare a short oral
presentation to share their findings with the class, focusing on the most interesting cultural or historical
aspects, key festivals, and the proposed solutions to local problems. The assignment will be evaluated by
using rubrics.

tema: THEME 14: LIFE IN THE WORLD AND CULTURE
konu:
Sub-themes: “Capitals of countries; landmarks and famous places in capitals and cities; cultural differences in different parts of the world”
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for capitals of countries:
London- England, Berlin- Germany, Madrid- Spain, Athens- Greece, Vienna- Austria, Beijing- China, Islamabad- Pakistan, Seoul-South Korea, Washington, D.C. -the USA, Moscow-Russia, Baku-Azerbaijan, Nur-Sultan-Kazakhstan, Ashgabat- Turkmenistan, Bishkek- Kyrgyzstan, Tashkent- Uzbekistan, Budapest- Hungary, Lefkosia (Nicosia) -Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, Rome-Italy, Paris-France.
Vocabulary for landmarks and famous places in capitals and cities:
Nouns: A tourist attraction, a historical site, a city hall, an embassy, a world heritage (site), population. Verbs:To go abroad, to go sightseeing, to explore, to admire, to represent, to protect, to preserve, to walk around.
Landmarks: The Hagia Sophia Grand Mosque- Türkiye, Blue Mosque- Türkiye, Eiffel Tower- France, Taj Mahal-India, Colosseum-Italy, Big Ben -London, Sydney Opera House- Australia, Galata Tower- Türkiye, Sagrada Familia- Spain, the Pyramids of Giza- Egypt, the Great wall of China-China,
Adjectives: Iconic, historic, ancient, modern, impressive, breathtaking, awesome, must-see, (to be) worth seeing, inspiring.
Vocabulary for cultural differences in different parts of the world:
Nouns: Culture, festivals, traditions, customs, beliefs, superstitions, hospitality, cuisine, religion, traditional dresses, similarities. Adjectives: Multicultural, familiar, foreign, tolerant. Verbs: To greet, to respect, to adapt, to celebrate, to influence, to compare, to experience, to be aware.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use
(Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms):
-The Simple Present Tense: (She always admires the architecture of the Blue Mosque in İstanbul.)
-The Present Progressive Tense-: (They’re / are visiting the Pyramids of Giza now.)
-The Present Perfect Tense: (I’ve / have visited the Hagia Sofia many times so far.)
-The Present Perfect Progressive Tense: (He’s / has been exploring the historic sites in Türkiye since last month.)
-The Simple Past Tense: (She visited the Great Wall of China last year.)
-The Past Progressive Tense: (He was walking around the Colosseum in Rome when it started to rain.)
-The Simple Future Tense): (She’ll / will go sightseeing in Madrid next week.)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Past Perfect Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (We had visited the museum before we had lunch. We hadn’t /had not visited the museum before we had lunch. Had you visited the museum before you had lunch?)
-Reported Speech with Mixed Tenses (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms):
(The Simple Present Tense): (She said that she admired the architecture of the Blue Mosque in İstanbul.)
(The Present Progressive Tense): (They told us that they were visiting the Pyramids of Giza the following day.)(The Present Perfect Tense): (He reported that he had explored the historic sites in Türkiye.)
(The Present Perfect Progressive Tense): (She said that she had been admiring the Galata Tower for years.)
(The Simple Past Tense): (She said that she had visited the Great Wall of China the previous year.)
(The Past Perfect Tense): (He said that he had already seen the Sydney Opera House before visiting the museum.)
(The Simple Future Tense): (She said that she would go sightseeing in Madrid the following week.)
(Be Going to Future Tense): (They asked if they were going to visit the Taj Mahal that summer.) Verbs: To say, to tell, to ask, to report, to order, to request. Answers: with: “Yes and no”.
-Modals in the past (Could/Should/Would/Might have V3) (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms):
Could have + V3: (Expressing ability: She could have finished the project but she didn’t / did not have enough resources.)
Should have + V3: (Expressing advice: He should have explored the historical sites in Berlin last summer.)
Would have + V3: (Expressing hypothetical situations: They would have gone sightseeing in Paris if they had had more time.)
May have + V3: (Expressing past possibility: He may have been to the Colosseum, but I’m not sure).
Might have + V3: (Expressing uncertainty or possibility: She might have visited the Eiffel Tower when she was in France).
-Be Going to Future Tense: (They’re / are going to visit the Taj Mahal this summer.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Simple Present Tense: Expressing, habits, routines, and facts.
-The Present Progressive Tense-: Expressing actions happening now.
-The Present Perfect Tense: Expressing actions done at an unspecified time until now.
-The Present Perfect Progressive Tense: Expression actions that started in the past and are still continuing.
-The Simple Past Tense: Expressing actions finished in the past.
-The Past Progressive Tense: Expressing actions happening at a specific moment in the past.
-The Simple Future Tense): Expressing future actions and/or plans.
-Be Going to Future Tense: Expressing planned future actions.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Reported Speech: Expressing what someone else has said, asked, or instructed (by changing verb tenses, pronouns, and time expressions appropriately) to reflect indirect speech.
-Use of the Past Perfect Tense: Describing one past action or event happened before another past action or event. (It makes the order of past events clear.)
-Use of Modals in the past (Could/Should/Would/Might have V3): Expressing unrealised possibilities or abilities, advice or criticism about past actions, hypothetical or imagined situations, and uncertainty about whether something happened.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
All roads lead to Rome!
Ankara is the heartbeat of our nation!
Power meets culture there!
A bridge to the past!
A melting pot of cultures!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonants: v, w
Consonants: v: (/viː/, /v/); w: (/w/), silent /w/).
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

tema: THEME 14: LIFE IN THE WORLD AND CULTURE
konu:
Sub-themes: “Capitals of countries; landmarks and famous places in capitals and cities; cultural differences in different parts of the world”
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for capitals of countries:
London- England, Berlin- Germany, Madrid- Spain, Athens- Greece, Vienna- Austria, Beijing- China, Islamabad- Pakistan, Seoul-South Korea, Washington, D.C. -the USA, Moscow-Russia, Baku-Azerbaijan, Nur-Sultan-Kazakhstan, Ashgabat- Turkmenistan, Bishkek- Kyrgyzstan, Tashkent- Uzbekistan, Budapest- Hungary, Lefkosia (Nicosia) -Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, Rome-Italy, Paris-France.
Vocabulary for landmarks and famous places in capitals and cities:
Nouns: A tourist attraction, a historical site, a city hall, an embassy, a world heritage (site), population. Verbs:To go abroad, to go sightseeing, to explore, to admire, to represent, to protect, to preserve, to walk around.
Landmarks: The Hagia Sophia Grand Mosque- Türkiye, Blue Mosque- Türkiye, Eiffel Tower- France, Taj Mahal-India, Colosseum-Italy, Big Ben -London, Sydney Opera House- Australia, Galata Tower- Türkiye, Sagrada Familia- Spain, the Pyramids of Giza- Egypt, the Great wall of China-China,
Adjectives: Iconic, historic, ancient, modern, impressive, breathtaking, awesome, must-see, (to be) worth seeing, inspiring.
Vocabulary for cultural differences in different parts of the world:
Nouns: Culture, festivals, traditions, customs, beliefs, superstitions, hospitality, cuisine, religion, traditional dresses, similarities. Adjectives: Multicultural, familiar, foreign, tolerant. Verbs: To greet, to respect, to adapt, to celebrate, to influence, to compare, to experience, to be aware.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use
(Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms):
-The Simple Present Tense: (She always admires the architecture of the Blue Mosque in İstanbul.)
-The Present Progressive Tense-: (They’re / are visiting the Pyramids of Giza now.)
-The Present Perfect Tense: (I’ve / have visited the Hagia Sofia many times so far.)
-The Present Perfect Progressive Tense: (He’s / has been exploring the historic sites in Türkiye since last month.)
-The Simple Past Tense: (She visited the Great Wall of China last year.)
-The Past Progressive Tense: (He was walking around the Colosseum in Rome when it started to rain.)
-The Simple Future Tense): (She’ll / will go sightseeing in Madrid next week.)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Past Perfect Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (We had visited the museum before we had lunch. We hadn’t /had not visited the museum before we had lunch. Had you visited the museum before you had lunch?)
-Reported Speech with Mixed Tenses (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms):
(The Simple Present Tense): (She said that she admired the architecture of the Blue Mosque in İstanbul.)
(The Present Progressive Tense): (They told us that they were visiting the Pyramids of Giza the following day.)(The Present Perfect Tense): (He reported that he had explored the historic sites in Türkiye.)
(The Present Perfect Progressive Tense): (She said that she had been admiring the Galata Tower for years.)
(The Simple Past Tense): (She said that she had visited the Great Wall of China the previous year.)
(The Past Perfect Tense): (He said that he had already seen the Sydney Opera House before visiting the museum.)
(The Simple Future Tense): (She said that she would go sightseeing in Madrid the following week.)
(Be Going to Future Tense): (They asked if they were going to visit the Taj Mahal that summer.) Verbs: To say, to tell, to ask, to report, to order, to request. Answers: with: “Yes and no”.
-Modals in the past (Could/Should/Would/Might have V3) (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms):
Could have + V3: (Expressing ability: She could have finished the project but she didn’t / did not have enough resources.)
Should have + V3: (Expressing advice: He should have explored the historical sites in Berlin last summer.)
Would have + V3: (Expressing hypothetical situations: They would have gone sightseeing in Paris if they had had more time.)
May have + V3: (Expressing past possibility: He may have been to the Colosseum, but I’m not sure).
Might have + V3: (Expressing uncertainty or possibility: She might have visited the Eiffel Tower when she was in France).
-Be Going to Future Tense: (They’re / are going to visit the Taj Mahal this summer.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Simple Present Tense: Expressing, habits, routines, and facts.
-The Present Progressive Tense-: Expressing actions happening now.
-The Present Perfect Tense: Expressing actions done at an unspecified time until now.
-The Present Perfect Progressive Tense: Expression actions that started in the past and are still continuing.
-The Simple Past Tense: Expressing actions finished in the past.
-The Past Progressive Tense: Expressing actions happening at a specific moment in the past.
-The Simple Future Tense): Expressing future actions and/or plans.
-Be Going to Future Tense: Expressing planned future actions.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Reported Speech: Expressing what someone else has said, asked, or instructed (by changing verb tenses, pronouns, and time expressions appropriately) to reflect indirect speech.
-Use of the Past Perfect Tense: Describing one past action or event happened before another past action or event. (It makes the order of past events clear.)
-Use of Modals in the past (Could/Should/Would/Might have V3): Expressing unrealised possibilities or abilities, advice or criticism about past actions, hypothetical or imagined situations, and uncertainty about whether something happened.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
All roads lead to Rome!
Ankara is the heartbeat of our nation!
Power meets culture there!
A bridge to the past!
A melting pot of cultures!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonants: v, w
Consonants: v: (/viː/, /v/); w: (/w/), silent /w/).
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

tema: THEME 15: LIFE IN NATURE AND GLOBAL PROBLEMS
konu:
Sub-themes: "Natural resources, animals in nature and their habitats, protecting natural resources and animals"
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for natural resources:
Nouns: Habitat, effect, recycling, sustainability, conservation, protection, pollution, erosion, destruction, waste, shortage.
Vocabulary for types of natural resources:
Nouns: Renewable resources (solar energy, wind energy, and hydroelectric power), non-renewable resources (coal, natural gas, and crude oil), living resources (forests, animals, and marine life), non-living resources (minerals like iron and gold, and resources like air and water).
Vocabulary for the use of natural resources:
Verbs: To generate, to supply, to maintain, to consume, to waste.
Vocabulary for the protection of natural resources:
Verbs: To protect, to preserve, to support, to prevent, to avoid, to reuse, to recycle, to restore, to replant, to affect, to pollute, to reduce, to destroy, to damage, to conserve. Phrases for natural resources: Greenhouse gases, greenhouse effect, carbon footprint, global warming, climate change, fossil fuel, energy/resource consumption, energy efficiency, clean energy, zero waste, wildlife preservation, sustainable development, eco-friendly.
Vocabulary for types of animals:
Nouns: Mammal, reptile, amphibian, insect, carnivore, herbivore, omnivore, endangered species.
Vocabulary for animal behaviours (behavior AmE.):
Nouns: Predator, prey, species, hunting, nesting.
Vocabulary for animal habitats:
Nouns: Habitat loss, hunting, poaching, extinction, a jungle, a desert, a savanna, wetland, grassland, steppe.
Vocabulary for animal features:
Nouns: A scale, a claw, a horn, a beak, a trunk, a whisker, a fin.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use
-The Past Perfect Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The team had cleaned the beach before the tourists came). The team hadn’t / had not cleaned the beach before the tourists came). (Had the team cleaned the beach before the tourists came?)
-Needn’t, Mustn’t (for Obligation): (You needn’t come to shopping if you are busy) (You mustn’t go out of the school now.)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Past Perfect Progressive Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms) (The volunteers had been helping animals before the fire ended. The volunteers hadn’t / had not been helping animals before the fire ended. Had the volunteers been helping animals before the fire ended?)
-Third Conditional (3) (Unreal Past Situations): If he had studied harder, he would have passed the exam); (Hypothetical outcomes in the past: We would have met at the café, if you had remembered); (Regret or criticism: If I had known about traffic, I would have left earlier.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Past Perfect Tense: Describing an action or state completed before another action or point in the past.
-Use of ''Needn’t, Mustn’t (for obligation)'': Expressing strong obligation (and prohibition) not to do something.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Past Perfect Progressive Tense: Describes an action that was going over a period of time before another action or point in the past. 
-Use of the Third Conditional (3): Expressing an unreal past situation and its imagined (hypothetical) result situations.
-Use of Modals in the past with the Third Conditional (3): Expressing lack of necessity and absence of obligation.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
Let’s put a drop in the ocean!
Our forests are running on empty!
Live off the land!
That’s the tip of the iceberg!
Pollution is a cloud on the horizon!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonants: x, y
Consonants: x: (/ɛks/, /ks/, /gz/); y: (/waɪ/, /j/, /ɪ/, /iː/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

Assessment and Evaluation Scheme for Upper Secondary Schools

PERFORMANCE ASSIGNMENT: Students will design and present a project that explores the challenges
and solutions related to natural resources, wildlife, and environmental protection. They will research the
importance of conserving natural resources and animal habitats, analyse the effects of human activity
on nature, and propose actionable steps for a more sustainable future. As part of the project, students
will write reports, create visual aids (such as posters or presentations), and role-play as conservationists,
scientists, or environmental activists. They will simulate scenarios like addressing climate change,
protecting endangered species, or raising awareness about sustainable practices. The assignment will be
evaluated using rubrics.

tema: THEME 15: LIFE IN NATURE AND GLOBAL PROBLEMS
konu:
Sub-themes: "Natural resources, animals in nature and their habitats, protecting natural resources and animals"
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for natural resources:
Nouns: Habitat, effect, recycling, sustainability, conservation, protection, pollution, erosion, destruction, waste, shortage.
Vocabulary for types of natural resources:
Nouns: Renewable resources (solar energy, wind energy, and hydroelectric power), non-renewable resources (coal, natural gas, and crude oil), living resources (forests, animals, and marine life), non-living resources (minerals like iron and gold, and resources like air and water).
Vocabulary for the use of natural resources:
Verbs: To generate, to supply, to maintain, to consume, to waste.
Vocabulary for the protection of natural resources:
Verbs: To protect, to preserve, to support, to prevent, to avoid, to reuse, to recycle, to restore, to replant, to affect, to pollute, to reduce, to destroy, to damage, to conserve. Phrases for natural resources: Greenhouse gases, greenhouse effect, carbon footprint, global warming, climate change, fossil fuel, energy/resource consumption, energy efficiency, clean energy, zero waste, wildlife preservation, sustainable development, eco-friendly.
Vocabulary for types of animals:
Nouns: Mammal, reptile, amphibian, insect, carnivore, herbivore, omnivore, endangered species.
Vocabulary for animal behaviours (behavior AmE.):
Nouns: Predator, prey, species, hunting, nesting.
Vocabulary for animal habitats:
Nouns: Habitat loss, hunting, poaching, extinction, a jungle, a desert, a savanna, wetland, grassland, steppe.
Vocabulary for animal features:
Nouns: A scale, a claw, a horn, a beak, a trunk, a whisker, a fin.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use
-The Past Perfect Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The team had cleaned the beach before the tourists came). The team hadn’t / had not cleaned the beach before the tourists came). (Had the team cleaned the beach before the tourists came?)
-Needn’t, Mustn’t (for Obligation): (You needn’t come to shopping if you are busy) (You mustn’t go out of the school now.)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Past Perfect Progressive Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms) (The volunteers had been helping animals before the fire ended. The volunteers hadn’t / had not been helping animals before the fire ended. Had the volunteers been helping animals before the fire ended?)
-Third Conditional (3) (Unreal Past Situations): If he had studied harder, he would have passed the exam); (Hypothetical outcomes in the past: We would have met at the café, if you had remembered); (Regret or criticism: If I had known about traffic, I would have left earlier.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Past Perfect Tense: Describing an action or state completed before another action or point in the past.
-Use of ''Needn’t, Mustn’t (for obligation)'': Expressing strong obligation (and prohibition) not to do something.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Past Perfect Progressive Tense: Describes an action that was going over a period of time before another action or point in the past. 
-Use of the Third Conditional (3): Expressing an unreal past situation and its imagined (hypothetical) result situations.
-Use of Modals in the past with the Third Conditional (3): Expressing lack of necessity and absence of obligation.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
Let’s put a drop in the ocean!
Our forests are running on empty!
Live off the land!
That’s the tip of the iceberg!
Pollution is a cloud on the horizon!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonants: x, y
Consonants: x: (/ɛks/, /ks/, /gz/); y: (/waɪ/, /j/, /ɪ/, /iː/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

PERFORMANCE ASSIGNMENT: Students will design and present a project that explores the challenges
and solutions related to natural resources, wildlife, and environmental protection. They will research the
importance of conserving natural resources and animal habitats, analyse the effects of human activity
on nature, and propose actionable steps for a more sustainable future. As part of the project, students
will write reports, create visual aids (such as posters or presentations), and role-play as conservationists,
scientists, or environmental activists. They will simulate scenarios like addressing climate change,
protecting endangered species, or raising awareness about sustainable practices. The assignment will be
evaluated using rubrics.

Objective: To help students reflect on environmental issues in English by using target grammar and target vocabulary in a meaningful context to describe past actions and suggest better solutions.

tema: THEME 15: LIFE IN NATURE AND GLOBAL PROBLEMS
konu:
Sub-themes: "Natural resources, animals in nature and their habitats, protecting natural resources and animals"
Target Vocabulary in Use (with revisional vocabulary):
Vocabulary for natural resources:
Nouns: Habitat, effect, recycling, sustainability, conservation, protection, pollution, erosion, destruction, waste, shortage.
Vocabulary for types of natural resources:
Nouns: Renewable resources (solar energy, wind energy, and hydroelectric power), non-renewable resources (coal, natural gas, and crude oil), living resources (forests, animals, and marine life), non-living resources (minerals like iron and gold, and resources like air and water).
Vocabulary for the use of natural resources:
Verbs: To generate, to supply, to maintain, to consume, to waste.
Vocabulary for the protection of natural resources:
Verbs: To protect, to preserve, to support, to prevent, to avoid, to reuse, to recycle, to restore, to replant, to affect, to pollute, to reduce, to destroy, to damage, to conserve. Phrases for natural resources: Greenhouse gases, greenhouse effect, carbon footprint, global warming, climate change, fossil fuel, energy/resource consumption, energy efficiency, clean energy, zero waste, wildlife preservation, sustainable development, eco-friendly.
Vocabulary for types of animals:
Nouns: Mammal, reptile, amphibian, insect, carnivore, herbivore, omnivore, endangered species.
Vocabulary for animal behaviours (behavior AmE.):
Nouns: Predator, prey, species, hunting, nesting.
Vocabulary for animal habitats:
Nouns: Habitat loss, hunting, poaching, extinction, a jungle, a desert, a savanna, wetland, grassland, steppe.
Vocabulary for animal features:
Nouns: A scale, a claw, a horn, a beak, a trunk, a whisker, a fin.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use
-The Past Perfect Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The team had cleaned the beach before the tourists came). The team hadn’t / had not cleaned the beach before the tourists came). (Had the team cleaned the beach before the tourists came?)
-Needn’t, Mustn’t (for Obligation): (You needn’t come to shopping if you are busy) (You mustn’t go out of the school now.)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Past Perfect Progressive Tense: (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms) (The volunteers had been helping animals before the fire ended. The volunteers hadn’t / had not been helping animals before the fire ended. Had the volunteers been helping animals before the fire ended?)
-Third Conditional (3) (Unreal Past Situations): If he had studied harder, he would have passed the exam); (Hypothetical outcomes in the past: We would have met at the café, if you had remembered); (Regret or criticism: If I had known about traffic, I would have left earlier.)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Past Perfect Tense: Describing an action or state completed before another action or point in the past.
-Use of ''Needn’t, Mustn’t (for obligation)'': Expressing strong obligation (and prohibition) not to do something.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Past Perfect Progressive Tense: Describes an action that was going over a period of time before another action or point in the past. 
-Use of the Third Conditional (3): Expressing an unreal past situation and its imagined (hypothetical) result situations.
-Use of Modals in the past with the Third Conditional (3): Expressing lack of necessity and absence of obligation.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
Let’s put a drop in the ocean!
Our forests are running on empty!
Live off the land!
That’s the tip of the iceberg!
Pollution is a cloud on the horizon!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonants: x, y
Consonants: x: (/ɛks/, /ks/, /gz/); y: (/waɪ/, /j/, /ɪ/, /iː/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

tema: THEME 16: LIFE IN THE UNIVERSE AND FUTURE
konu:
Sub-themes: “Astronaut life on space stations; space explorations; life in the future”
Target Vocabulary in Use:
Vocabulary for Space:
Nouns: An alien, a galaxy, a planet, a probe, an asteroid, a comet, a mission, a sample, a spacecraft, data, outer space, gravity, habitat. Adjectives: Lunar, cosmic, harsh, revolutionary, artificial, interplanetary. Verbs: To explore, to launch, to orbit, to capture, to colonise, to navigate, to rotate, to revolve. Equipment for space explorations: Nouns: A space shuttle, a rocket, a space capsule, a satellite, a space suit.
Vocabulary for technology and innovation in the future:
Nouns: Artificial intelligence (AI), automation, robotics, nanotechnology, virtual reality (VR), space
colonisation.
Vocabulary for future life:
Nouns: Globalisation, urbanisation, bioengineering, cyber security, lifespan. Adjectives: Remote, autonomous, smart, flexible. Verbs: To influence, to extend, to enhance, to upgrade, to optimise, to simulate, to adapt, to evolve, to embrace, to sustain, to transplant, to promote.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Simple Future Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The team will prepare a project on space tourism next term. The team won’t/will not prepare a project on space tourism next term. Will the team prepare a project on space tourism next term?)
-The Present Perfect Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): The team have prepared a project on space tourism since last year.) The team haven’t / have not prepared a project on space tourism since last year. Have the team prepared a project on space tourism since last year?)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Future Perfect Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (By the year 2100, people will have colonised Mars and built sustainable habitats. (By the year 2100, people won’t / will not have built sustainable habitats. (By the year 2100, will people have colonised Mars and built sustainable habitats?)
-The Future Perfect Progressive Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (By 2050, researchers will have been exploring interplanetary travel for over three decades. By 2050, researchers won’t / will not have been exploring interplanetary travel for over three decades. By 2050, will researchers have been exploring interplanetary travel for over three decades?)
-Question Tags with the Future Perfect Tense: (Scientists will have completed the mission to collect asteroid samples, won’t they?) (We won’t / will not have completed the moon station by 2035, will we?)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Simple Future Tense (will): Describing actions or events that will happen in the future by expressing decisions, predictions, offers, and promises.
-The Present Perfect Tense: Expressing actions that happened at an unspecified time before now or still affect now.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Future Perfect Tense: Describing actions that will be completed before a specific time in the future.
-Use of the Future Perfect Progressive Tense: Emphasising the duration of an action that will continue up until a specific time in the future.
-Use of Question Tags with the Future Perfect Tense: Seeking confirmation or agreement about future accomplishments or predictions.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
That is out of this world!
Humans shoot for the stars!
This space research is light-years ahead!
Blast from the past, rocket to the future!
I love my mother/father/friend to the moon and back!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonant: z
z: / (zed/ (Br), /ziː/ (AmE), /z/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

Adjectives: Lunar, cosmic, harsh, revolutionary, artificial, interplanetary. Verbs: To explore, to launch, to orbit, to capture, to colonise, to navigate, to rotate, to revolve. Equipment for space explorations: Nouns: A space shuttle, a rocket, a space capsule, a satellite, a space suit.
Vocabulary for technology and innovation in the future:
Nouns: Artificial intelligence (AI), automation, robotics, nanotechnology, virtual reality (VR), space
colonisation.
Vocabulary for future life:
Nouns: Globalisation, urbanisation, bioengineering, cyber security, lifespan. Adjectives: Remote, autonomous, smart, flexible. Verbs: To influence, to extend, to enhance, to upgrade, to optimise, to simulate, to adapt, to evolve, to embrace, to sustain, to transplant, to promote.
*National and religious days, festivals and celebrations: 29 October Republic Day'', ''23 April National Sovereignty and Children’s Day'', ''19 May Commemoration of Atatürk, Youth and Sports Day'', ''15 July Democracy and National Unity Day'', ''30 August Victory Day'', ''Eid al-Fitr (Eid-al-Ramadan)'', ''Festival of Sacrifice (Eid-al-Adha)''.
*(Relevant language content and (communicative) activities related to these national and religious days, festivals and celebrations will be developed and integrated across all themes and in all appropriate sections wherever and whenever possible.)
*Local Cultural, Social and Moral Considerations of the Theme
In this theme, specific examples, cases, situations, events, and practices reflecting Turkish social, cultural, and moral customs, traditions, and heritage will be included across all sub-topics. This consideration will be age-and-level appropriate and selected with the Turkish learners’ social and cultural context in mind. A table of contents for this section is provided in the introduction to the whole English Curriculum.
Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Simple Future Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (The team will prepare a project on space tourism next term. The team won’t/will not prepare a project on space tourism next term. Will the team prepare a project on space tourism next term?)
-The Present Perfect Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): The team have prepared a project on space tourism since last year.) The team haven’t / have not prepared a project on space tourism since last year. Have the team prepared a project on space tourism since last year?)
*About ''Background Grammatical Structures in Use'':
The ''Background Grammatical Structures'' in this section are not only revisional but also serve as contextual support and contribute to meaning-making. They are intended to be used within the theme to help students grasp the meaning of the language constructed through the use of ''Target Grammatical Structures'' without being explicitly taught. These structures are not considered ''Target Grammatical Structures'' themselves rather they function as a part of the facilitation process, supporting both the target forms and the contexts in which they are used. They provide opportunities for learning through revised and scaffolded language.
Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-The Future Perfect Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (By the year 2100, people will have colonised Mars and built sustainable habitats. (By the year 2100, people won’t / will not have built sustainable habitats. (By the year 2100, will people have colonised Mars and built sustainable habitats?)
-The Future Perfect Progressive Tense (Positive, Negative, and Interrogative Forms): (By 2050, researchers will have been exploring interplanetary travel for over three decades. By 2050, researchers won’t / will not have been exploring interplanetary travel for over three decades. By 2050, will researchers have been exploring interplanetary travel for over three decades?)
-Question Tags with the Future Perfect Tense: (Scientists will have completed the mission to collect asteroid samples, won’t they?) (We won’t / will not have completed the moon station by 2035, will we?)
Functions of the Background Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Simple Future Tense (will): Describing actions or events that will happen in the future by expressing decisions, predictions, offers, and promises.
-The Present Perfect Tense: Expressing actions that happened at an unspecified time before now or still affect now.
Functions of the Target Grammatical Structures in Use:
-Use of the Future Perfect Tense: Describing actions that will be completed before a specific time in the future.
-Use of the Future Perfect Progressive Tense: Emphasising the duration of an action that will continue up until a specific time in the future.
-Use of Question Tags with the Future Perfect Tense: Seeking confirmation or agreement about future accomplishments or predictions.
Target Social Language Expressions in Use:
That is out of this world!
Humans shoot for the stars!
This space research is light-years ahead!
Blast from the past, rocket to the future!
I love my mother/father/friend to the moon and back!
Target Phonological Sounds in Use:
Consonant: z
z: / (zed/ (Br), /ziː/ (AmE), /z/)
*(Phonetic symbols will not be taught. Only sounds will be practised through the target words in the theme.)

Assessment and Evaluation Scheme for Upper Secondary Schools

PERFORMANCE ASSIGNMENT: Students will design and write a project that envisions humanity’s future in
space, exploring topics such as space exploration missions and predictions for life in the future. They will
focus on creating detailed plans for hypothetical space colonies, interplanetary travel, and the challenges
of living in outer space. Students will develop scripts for astronauts, scientists, and futuristic innovators
who are involved in space explorations and technological advancements. Through role-playing, they will
simulate missions, debates, and discoveries. They will use the target vocabulary and grammar to develop
persuasive arguments, present scientific findings, and hypothesise about the future of humanity in the
cosmos. The project will be presented in the class where they act out their roles, supported by visuals. The
assignment will be evaluated using rubrics.
